values: There was a power surge today during the thunderstorm and all of the computers reset. Well, my server didn't...so I turned it back on. Soon after, I realized that the hard drive with all of my full albums on it wasn't mounted. It's unreadable. It still appears to be spinning, and it's not a problem with the circuit board (as I swapped it with an identical one with no avail). Heck, the freezer trick didn't even work. It's not clicking, and I don't believe it's making any unusual sounds. The bottom line is that the computer sees it, but can't read from it. RIP 18,000 songs :-( ...anyone happen to have a clean room? :-D

Most likely. I rarely post here anymore, so...yeah. I'll still check the friends page, regardless of how often I actually post there ;-) If you're actually interested in what I'm up to (haha, I'm sure), then you can check out my Blog that I just started! :-) I couldn't even get "TheMattrix" as a username there...how lame is that!? Anyway...later!

I don't really know how to put this, but right now it seems like I'm stuck in an extremely good dream, where things are too good to be true. Maybe it's just because I'm tired at the moment and things seem surreal, but my one wish is that I never have to wake up from this dream.
Mom: "Oh, they saw the Erie Canal." Me: "They went to Panama!?"

I feel like I'm trying to treat a wound, but the best remedy would be simply to leave it alone and let it heal itself. The thing that really bothers me about it, though, is that I have no idea how it got there, or how to prevent myself from getting another one.

I find the amount of crap that people put up with when using their computers to be truely amazing. I mean, think about it. You spend, say, a grand on a new PC, only to have it loaded up with malware and running at a tenth of the original speed within a month. After spending so much money, should you really have to deal with all that? The thing is that most people are simply uninformed when it comes to such things. They don't take the time to learn how to deal with malware and protect against it in the first place, so when it hits, it keeps on a comin'. Around 90% of all PCs are infected with some sort of Spyware. What I want to do here is make a list of things people should know. I'll try to explain them all as simply as possible if you don't consider yourself to be very computer literate. Even if you do, you may still learn something!
[Disclaimer] to make this look more professional I'm still learning myself, so if any of this information is innaccurate, I left out something important, or anything needs clarifying, please let me know!
  [Note] some additional stuff about this guide to keep in mind Most of these links link to Wikipedia for more information. All programs linked to are Freeware.
  [A Few Things You Should Know] very important stuff, trust me - Internet Explorer (IE) sucks. Don't use it. Use Firefox instead. "All the spyware companies exploit bugs in Internet Explorer, so if you use FireFox, there's less of a chance of you getting spyware." - Greg - Norton sucks. Uninstall it. - WeatherBug is adware, not something that came with your computer. Uninstall it. - You're not supposed to have forty million tool bars (such as Hotbar) at the top of your web browser. If you have any that you didn't specifically install yourself, you have adware. See this? And this? Everything below the Address box shouldn't be there. Then again, you shouldn't be using IE anyway. - If you have Windows XP, install Service Pack 2. It has better malware protection and a fairly decent firewall which is good enough for most people's needs.
  [The programs you need] trust me, if you have a PC with an internet connection, you need this stuff Typically, you need one program for viruses and three for spyware. [Browser] IE is a horrible browser, and should never be used unless absolutely necissary. Firefox is where it's at. Trust me. Ditch IE now, and never use it again. No more popups, no more spyware. Just because IE comes with your computer doesn't mean you have to use it. There are always alternatives. [Virus] pick one Avast! Antivirus *OR* AVG Pick your favorite...personally, I like Avast! better, as it has more features. [Spyware/Adware] use all of them SpywareBlaster Ad-Aware Spybot Search & Destroy [Additional Programs] if the above just aren't enough Microsoft AntiSpyware AIMFix Download them. Install them. Use them.
[How to Use the Above Programs] if you can figure them out, skip this section [Avast! Antivirus] When you download it, they will email you a product key (which you don't have to enter until you open the main program.) Install Avast!, restart your computer, and you'll see two new system tray (bottom right of screen) icons - an 'i' and an 'a'. Right click on the 'i', and click on "Merge with main Avast! icon". (You don't need to do this, but having one icon is much cleaner than two.) Avast! will, by default, scan for new viruses in the background. However, to do a full system scan, right click on the 'a', go to "Start Avast! Antivirus", wait for it to finish performing the memory test, click "Continue", select the areas you want to scan (usually your C drive), and start the scan! Once you know the basics, Avast! will guide you through just about all of its features. [AVG] I don't actually have this installed on any of my computers anymore, so I can't give a very detailed walkthrough. If you need any help with it though, let me know! [SpywareBlaster] The purpose of this program is to fix web browser vulnerabilities (in Firefox and IE), which is how spyware typically gets in. Install it. Run it. Click on "Updates" (bottom left) then "Check for Updates" (bottom center). When that is complete, click on "Protection" (top left), then "Enable All Protection" under Quick Tasks at the bottom. For now, you're all set with this program. [Ad-Aware] As opposed to SpywareBlaster, Ad-Aware can not prevent spyware and adware - instead it scans your computer and deletes any that it finds. Install it. Run it. Click on "Check for updates now" (bottom right, above Start) every time you run the program and update it. When you're done with that and back to the main screen, click on "Start", and then "Next" to perform a Smart System Scan. When it is completed, select all of the found items (right click, there's an option in there for it), then delete them. [Spybot Search & Destroy] Spybot is like SpywareBlaster and Ad-Aware combined. It has a feature called "Immunize" that blocks spyware and it can also scan your computer. [Microsoft AntiSpyware] Still in Beta, but it can sometimes catch things that Ad-Aware and Spybot miss. Another nice feature of this program is that it takes care of a lot of things automatically. It'll detect attempted browser hijacks and spyware trying to install as they occur and block them. AntiSpyware has a lot more automated features than the others, but unless your computer gets really bad, you won't need it, and it'll just be taking up space. [AIMFix] Fixes all known viruses affecting AOL Instant Messanger. All you do is run it, it'll shut down AIM, kill virus processes, remove them, and display a list of all the problems it fixed. Very simple to use, no options or anything to mess around with.
  [When to Use the Above Programs] what's the point of having them if you don't use them? If your PC is in good running order, this is when you should run these programs. [Avast! Antivirus] Runs all the time in the background, but once a month or so, you should run a full scan. [AVG] Same as Avast! [SpywareBlaster] I would recommend updating and enabling all protection every two weeks, maximum. [Ad-Aware] You should perform a Smart Scan every several weeks. [Spybot Search & Destroy] Update, Immunize and scan every few weeks. [Microsoft AntiSpyware] Should automatically update, so just run a scan every few weeks or so. [AIMFix] If you have an AIM virus, run this.
  [Things You Should Avoid Doing] you know, like don't open email attachments from people you don't know - First of all, don't open email attachments from people you don't know. This is obvious. - If someone messages you on AIM with something like "Check out these pics from the beach!" And one of the words links somewhere, DON'T CLICK IT. Another good one is when it's something like "haha, this is hiliarious: http://www.funnystuff.com/crowbar.jpg". Looks like it links right to that, doesn't it? WELL IT DOESN'T. All they did was use a seemingly harmless URL as the text for another link. If you see anyone who sends you something like that, or you see it appear in their away message, message them and recommend that they run AIMFix before infecting other people. That's how these things spread. - For the love of God, don't click on anything inside of popup windows. I don't want to see any of this, "Oh hey! Shoot the monk, get an iPod!!! Sounds like my kind of game!!!" Of course, if you use Firefox, you won't get popup windows. - Don't scan with more than one Spyware/Adware type program at the same time. Use one at a time. It doesn't hurt anything, it's just inefficient.
  [Common Definitions] you should know what terms such as spyware mean, but definitions are boring, so I put these last [Virus] A big deal, but overhyped as to how much they'll slow your computer down. Instead, they tend to spread quickly and destroy data on your hard drive. They'll typically come in through open ports (non-firewalled), email attachments, or your internet browser (ie. IE). [Firewall] Protects your computer from external sources gaining access. [Spyware] Runs in the background on your computer (which in turn slows it down a bit), collecting and sending personal information back to whoever deployed it. 'Personal information' typically includes things such as browsing habbits and general computer usage habbits, not things such as credit card numbers, etc. "Spyware is a broad category of malicious software intended to intercept or take partial control of a computer's operation without the user's informed consent." [Adware] Less intrusive but more annoying than spyware. "These applications often present banner ads in pop-up windows or through a bar that appears on a computer screen." Adware also slows down the computer quite a bit. [Malware] "malicious software" - The collective term for all types of harmful programs.
  [In Conclusion] so I can wrap this up before I go to work Ok, so what do I do when I fix someone's computer from malware? All I do is install either Avast! or AVG, SpywareBlaster, Ad-Aware, Spybot, and MS AntiSpyware and AIMFix if need be. Then I just run them all. Most of the time this is all that needs to be done. Sometimes there's really nasty things like viruses running in pairs that if you end one the other restarts the process and you can't kill both at the same time. And sometimes, the whole system is just so far gone that what it really needs is a fresh installation of Windows and a new start. Anyway, I hope this guide helps, and I'm sure I'll update it sometime!

Read it. You'll enjoy it, trust me ;-) Ok, so last Thursday night. Game 7. That was the day we were going down to Ohio for the wedding. We were staying in Angi's apartment (that she is now moved out of), and she didn't have a TV or a cable connection...so my dad decided to bring our TV since it's only a 13", and we use an antenna anyway. Well, the game was going to start at 9, and the apartment is just one room (other than the bathroom), so instead of disrupt my mom and sister with the game, my dad rigged up a headphone splitter (mono -> stereo -> dual mono -> each one going to stereo for the headphones) for which he had to make several trips to Radio Shack for. On the first trip, he also picked up a new antenna, since ours was partially falling apart. So anyway, later that night when we were in the apartment, we set up the contraption at about quarter to nine, to tune into the game. ABC is apparently channel 5 around those parts, so that's what we tried to get in. Well...it wouldn't come in at all. Not one bit. So we moved the TV to the door to try to get better reception...but channel 5 still wouldn't come in at all. We tried some other channels and found that we could get the game in slightly on channel 7, but only in black in white, really fuzzy, and with no sound. Alright, so then we moved the TV outside onto the patio, and we could get the picture in color, but still pretty fuzzy and no sound at all. But wait - then I had a brilliant idea! Watch the game on the TV without sound, and at the same time, tune it in on the radio! Well, that didn't work so well either, because we couldn't get in any station broadcasting the game (they only do such things on AM, but we tried FM too, just in case). Well, that idea didn't work so well, so where can we get a better radio? ... the car! So I went to the car, and flipped through every single AM station until I found that 1000 is ESPN Cleavland or something, but it took a while to find because the auto-tune skips over it every time because it doesn't come in very strong from where we were. My dad joined me in the car, but went back to put away the TV at the next commercial break. When he came back, he said "we're going somewhere where we can watch the game." Apparently, my mom called a Sports Bar & Grill and found that they were watching the game there, so she wrote down directions for us that the guy gave her, and so we headed off. The guy said head down Broadway, turn left on 6th Street, and it's on this other street down past some hospital. Well, we headed down Broadway and soon found out that 6th Street doesn't go left, so we turned right instead. Now, how to get from 6th to this other street the Bar & Grille was on? Turns out that these were the crappiest directions ever and 6th doesn't even remotely connect to this other street, and ended about 4 miles away from this place. Luckly, we had a map of Lorain and I looked up the location of this place on the street listing, but not before we turned around several times. Ha, so anyway, eventually we got there after the third quarter had already started. We sat down at a table, but after my dad's arm stuck to it and he had to go wash it off, we looked for another one. There ended up being like one table that wasn't gooey, so we sat there. There was only one guy running the place...really, I don't know how they afforded 6 plasma TV's. Ahhh...well after we finally got some food, we sat back and watched the last 1/3 of the game as the Pistons lost. But don't get me wrong, it actually was a pretty entertaining night :-)
Michigan Tech was awesome and the wedding was ridiculous. Want more, talk to me.

Yesterday was a lot of fun! Basically, me, Anthony, Brock, Lauren, Courtney, and Katie had an awesome barbeque at Stony Creek, then Anthony and I went mountian biking afterwards. I got up way earlier than usual (alright, so it was like 9:30), took a shower, and went over to Farmer Jack to get a pie and some cinnimon rolls to take to the barbeque. Anthony made some bread to take.
After 12:15 mass, I waited for Anth to arrive so we could load my bike onto the bike rack on the back of his car.
We ended up using my bike lock as the final security measure for the bikes, which is actually a pretty good idea if you think about it. It secures the bikes to the rack and it stops someone from quickly grabbing the bikes and running off. So anyway, then we went over to Brock's where everyone else was waiting for us, and then all headed out towards Stony. Well, at least we were hoping it was Stony when we were following Brock there...'cause we took the most inefficient route possible to get there, and it ended up taking like 40 minutes. Once we got there, it was a lot of fun though. We played frisbee and circle-volleyball (the picture is the latter), and had lots of good food. :-)
Aaaand it was really hot out there, so it probably didn't last as long as it would have.
Eventually, we packed up and Anthony and I headed over to the other side of Stony to go biking. We didn't know quite how to get there, so Brock led us to Stony Creek High School via another incredibly inefficient (once again) route through Rochester's back alleys and subdivisions. We parked in a nearby subdivision, across from the entrance we usually take into the biking paths.
Both of us have ridden the trails before, but neither of us really knew our way around, so it took a little while to find the enterance to the first trail we usually ride. But after we did, it wasn't too bad and I managed to find the other trails pretty well. On the first trail, Anth kind of rode off the right side of that bridge and ran into a tree. (I hear Jeff called this one ;-) Not too many slow-downs after that until he took down another tree a while later...this time with pictures!
Alright, I'm out of pics...but this is where it gets exciting! After the hill where it splits off and we could either go straight or right...we decided to go right. Eventually we came to another split where we could go left or right, and both of us remember going right at that point before, so that's what we did. However, that took us back out to the regular park, so we decided to go back and take the other way. Well, that's what we were going to do until the huge, dark thunderstorm clouds came out of nowhere and the winds picked up. Another biker who just rode out of the woods where we had come from told us that we should probably seek shelter in the bathroom (the only sheltered place around) until the rains subsided. At this point, it hadn't even started raining yet, so we debated whether or not to try to make a dash for the car, which was probably about a mile or so away. Turned out to be a good thing we didn't, cause it started raining a few minutes later with huge, cold drops. So we chilled in the bathroom for a little while with our bikes, and then went back outside to decide what to do. By the time the rain subsided, it would probably be too dark to ride the paths back to the car (it was almost 9:00), and there would probably be huge mud puddles and branches all over the paths....so we decided to take the main roads back to the car. We didn't have to think about it too long though, cause there was a very nice couple sitting in their van in the parking lot who eventually drove over and asked if we needed a lift with our bikes back to our car. By this time, it was raining extremely hard, so we loaded our bikes up in the van. I've seen some pretty hard rain before, but I really don't think I've ever seen it rain that hard in my entire life. Anyway, it was a tight fit with his and his wife's bikes in there also. I stood in the back with the bikes (and no it really wasn't that bad back there), and Anthony rode in the front. So we got back to the car and thanked them for the ride, and by this time it had mostly stopped raining. After loading the bikes up to the rack, we had some more bread and drove home, the most efficient way possible, of course ;-)

You reached the top of the mountain, and in a dream, almost, the stars were there! You could reach out and touch them, finally embracing the eternal glow. Waking from the dream, you find the fridged, snow-packed top to be no nearer to the stars than before the journey. So what will you do now, now that you've finally looked for yourself? Why couldn't you simply climb back down and go home? Why not? It would be so easy! It's because you would look up at the night sky again, no matter where you were, and the same wonder, awe, and inspiration would fill your eyes as last time. Sure, you could freeze up there, but in all honesty, there is no place on this earth where you would rather be - gazing up at the beauty, filling your vision, filling your thoughts.

Your Dominant Thinking Style:

Visioning You are very insightful and tend to make decisions based on your insights. You focus on how things should be - even if you haven't worked out the details. An idealist, thinking of the future helps you guide your path. You tend to give others long-term direction and momentum.

Your Secondary Thinking Style:

Exploring You thrive on the unknown and unpredictable. Novelty is your middle name. You are a challenger. You tend to challenge common assumptions and beliefs. An expert inventor and problem solver, you approach everything from new angles. You show people how to question their models of the world.
What's Your Thinking Style?

And sometimes, you're left to wonder, that perhaps even the mountain itself was an illusion to begin with? But no, you've scaled it...up...and up...every once in a while running into a snag, or slipping down a bit. Although you havn't reached the top yet, you know that the only thing awaiting you is dissapointment, so why make the climb? Perhaps it is the misguided hope that maybe, just maybe, there won't be dissapointment at the top. Why would you think that, though? No, it's a fool's hope - stop believing in fairy tails.
Well, looks like I got 30 hours this next week at OL :-)

Have you ever desired something tremendously, only to have that matched by your inability to obtain it? Like the countless stars in the night sky - beautiful, yet always out of reach. And what can bring you closer to them? Climbing the highest mountain may, at first, seem useful, but as soon as you reach the peak and gaze up at the stars once more, you'll realize that they are no nearer to you than before your immense effort. So why not stay on the ground where it's safe? The closest you can ever be is in your dreams.

Well, I stopped in at Organized Living today and just as I thought - they havn't scheduled me for this week, even though I asked them to. Well this is interesting. Haha, well...guess I'd better start applying around. So much for this new CEO that took over early last year to turn the company around, bringing in a new management board who fired all of the employees under 17 for the stupidest reasons. However, I enjoyed working there most of the time, but after a good 2 1/2 years or so maybe it's time to move on. I'm thinking about getting A+ certified, which is a general computer hardware/software certification, and from what I hear, it's pretty easy. The downside is that is costs almost $100 I think, so what I'll probably do is apply to some computer places around here first, then if none of them take me, I'll get certified and try again. Then if none still take me, I'll just have to try some other places I guess until I find someplace to make some money this summer. You might just find me on Eight Mile ;-)

Well, I havn't posted here in a while...probably because I havn't done anything worth mentioning for quite a long time. Not that I have now, but I'm bored and so decided to post. All I do right now is either sleep, eat, sit at the computer, work out, or work on homework...oh, wait - that's what I've been doing all year anyway. Monday evening, Mike Baker - my CS partner, came over around six so we could work on project 3 (a version of the game, Breakout), since we had to turn it in Tuesday morning at 11. To make a short story even shorter, we basically worked on it solid until then, and even a little into the class (so that's a good, what... 18 hours straight?) Mike hadn't gotten any sleep the previous night either, and I honestly don't know how he stayed awake Monday night. Well, actually - he did pass out at one point for a few minutes...and it was rather amusing. I tried waking him up, but nothing seemed to do the trick. I even picked up his arm and dropped it, but he didn't move. So I was like "I'll try again in a little bit..." but he woke up half a minute later by himself all confused and having no idea I was trying to wake him up. But anyway, check out the game!
The paddle's angle can be adjusted with the mouse buttons. Left-mouse button to raise the left side, right to raise the right, and both to push it all the way up. The darker bricks need to be hit twice to be destroyed. After one hit, they turn into the ligher bricks, then are destroyed after the next hit. Those bricks with cages are "item bricks" and after one hit, they dissapear and drop their item. (The only items in the game at the moment are ones that change the width of the paddle.) I still have many bugs to fix and a ton of stuff to add before it's actually worth playing. Adam - your Breakout on the other hand...now that's just dead sexy ;-) When mine is worth playing sometime this summer, you can be sure I'll make it into an applet so y'all can play it online and get addicted :-D I was actually hoping to get a bit further with the game....but oh well. (We also spent a good three to five hours working on ball to ball collisions, but never got it working well enough to implement into the final version...baaah!!)
I spontaniously got sick Monday night working on the CS project, and on Wednesday, my voice went to crap. Thursday I could barely talk at all, and overall today it's a bit better than it was Wednesday, so I think I'm getting better. This morning was interesting, though. I woke up at 5am coughing and feeling like I was going to throw up...and then I did. After that I felt a bit better, but my stomache still feels weird. I'm hoping I'll be alllll better tomorrow :-) But since I was up at 5, I decided to do my wash, since I forgot to do it last night, so at least something good came out of it ;-) I should probably be studying for various exams right now, but I found the quickest way for me to start working on other things is to open up my Environmental Science book. Well, that or my European History book. Those classes will definitely contain my most difficult exams, followed by CS, then Math 225, then PLS 102 (if it's like the midterm) being the easiest exam. I found out today that I can get a 50% on my CS final and still get a 92% in the class...haha, but my Prof said that if I didn't get somewhere in the > 80% range, he'd write me a nasty note :-/ ...and if you read all that, you're my hero :-)
So on Tuesday the 26th, I have a final at 8am... then solid exams from noon 'till six. Oh goodness, that day will suck.
Is exactly like it is outside at the moment. I love it!

(Well, done yesterday, but I was too tired to post anything yesterday.) If you're curious, the goal of the project was to create a discrete (as opposed to real time) simulation of people entering/exiting several lines in the food court below Fresh Food. The results of the simulation would be displayed at the end. The GUI part was optional, but it's always nice to have extra points just in case we fudged something else up like the code, the layout of the code, or the UML. (That, and Photoshop is always fun when I feel like I should really be working on the project, but don't feel like coding ;-) (I pieced the food court overhead view together from this crappy picture...and I havn't been there in a while, so I'm not sure how accurate it is ;-) Good luck to all of you who have to turn the project in today! All of you. Yep, all. ...alright...fine - good luck, Adam ;-)

Break was pretty good, I guess. It seemed really short, probably because I slept so much. I got to use Jeff's ballin' $260 headphones for most of the week, so that was really nice. (You know what I'm talkin' about ;-) Let's see...well, Organized Living didn't give me any hours, so I worked at PC Mart for two days and made as much as I would have working at OL for three or four...and I got paid right away, instead of waiting a week or two weeks, so that was nice. On Friday I went skating with my mom to break in my skates. I guess a "factory edge" on the blades isn't what you want to be skating on though, 'cause I was slipping sideways on every turn. Of course, then I got them sharpened and now they're wonderful. My mom was showing me how to do some stuff and I ended up working on this one thing the whole time...I forget what it's called. It's like where you're skating in one direction and facing the same way, and then you spin around on one foot so that you're still skating the same direction but facing the other way. So yeah, I can almost do that now, just need a bit more practice. Oh, last night Caleb and I completely moved around our room. I like it a lot more and there's a whole lot more space in the middle of the room. Tomorrow I have a test in history that I'm going to fail miserably. So today I'm pretty much just going to be studying for that. There's a study group over at Kirkhof tonight at 8 that I'll probably go to as well. Oh goodness...I like that class...I just hate the tests. Oh well, I guess now I can look forward to tomorrow after my history class. :-) BLAH BLAH BLAH...Brock's birthday is on friday, but meh, who cares...it's only 19. LoL...I kno--- wait a second.... I've heard that somewhere before.... ;-)
Well, looks like Organized Living has been cutting back on hours recently, so I won't be making any money this week... :-|
I'm thinking about studying abroad for a semester during my junior year. In Sweden.
Dang it, I can't check my midterm grades 'cause I'm not a "freshman" (or in poor standing...which I guess is good).

So last night, Caleb and I went to get ice cream. We were walking back into Kistler with it when the fire alarm went off. We just kinda looked at the alarm...looked at eachother...were like "should we get spoons?" ... "oh yeah!" ... walked up the stairs to our room, grabbed some spoons, left the room, locked the door, and walked back down stairs and outside. Should have grabbed a coat, too, cause we were out there for like 40 minutes...that was fun. Haha, it was great when people were like "you're eating icecream, ouside in the cold in a short-sleeved shirt!?" But apparently...some moron on the second floor set a sign on fire, which then started the door on fire. But they don't know who did it (as far as I know), so the whole building is being charged for it.
Amazon.com has a new trailer for the Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy right on their main page! Check it out! It looks amazing. Oh man, it's hilarious....
